title: Liberals appoint a shadow minister for men
text:
﻿NSW Liberal leader Kelli Sloane has declared "masculinity should be celebrated" as she announced a new position in her team targeting men's health.

Davidson MP Matt Cross, who survived bowel cancer, has been named the state opposition's parliamentary secretary for men's health .

Although it is not a full shadow cabinet portfolio, Cross will effectively act as a shadow minister to improve the lives of boys and men through physical and mental health outcomes. ﻿

READ MORE: ﻿ Remains on Queensland farm belong to man who vanished in 2018

NSW Liberal Leader Kellie Sloane. (Sitthixay Ditthavong)

Sloane told 2GB Radio today the matter was close to her heart as a mother to three boys.﻿

"Before I was in this role as opposition leader, I was shadow health minister and I noticed the huge disparity in health outcomes between men and women, boys and girls," she said.

"Men are three times more likely than women to commit suicide. They will die four years earlier than women from avoidable causes, more likely to have cardiovascular disease, to have avoidable cancers, they don't go to the doctor as much.

"These are huge problems, and they're statistics that should absolutely stop us in our tracks."

Sloane ﻿said the conversation around men needed to change so that masculinity was "celebrated".

"We've got to stop saying that men need to be fixed, that they're broken, that they're toxic," she said.

"Let's turn that around and let's say you are supported, you are loved, and your masculinity should be celebrated."

The federal government has its own special envoy for men's health, Dan Repacholi, who was appointed last year, but Sloane said she wanted to "get serious about it" at the state level. ﻿

READ MORE: ﻿ Trump appears to back down as crisis hits breaking point

Davidson MP Matt Cross. (Facebook)

Cross said his new position was a "real honour" in a video he filmed on his way to meet his oncologist at Royal North Shore Hospital.

"Talking about men's health is just so important. We need to be able to start a conversation," he said.

"It's okay to be vulnerable﻿. It's about sharing our pains, sharing the need to support one another, and being human."

The NSW Liberals have also announced Jordan Lane as the new shadow parliamentary secretary for home ownership and rental affordability ﻿and Michael Kemp as the new shadow parliamentary secretary for the prevention of regional crime.

The NSW Liberals have 10 women and 16 men in their new opposition ministry.

NEVER MISS A STORY: Get your breaking news and exclusive stories first by following us across all platforms.

title: Cats are running wild in one state. This unpopular law may be the solution
text:
Pet cats are running wild in Western Australia and council attempts ﻿to control them keep resulting in failure and frustration, new research has found.

Cats are roaming the streets unregistered and without microchips﻿.

Many also haven't been desexed, which could contribute the state's stray and feral cat population.

Cats are running wild in one state and an unpopular law may be the solution. (Getty)

Now research from The University of Western Australia and Murdoch University has revealed that while the cats themselves may not be the problem, keeping them indoors could be the solution.

A survey of 103 of WA's 139 local government areas (LGAs) found there was poor community awareness of what responsible cat ownership involves.

WA's Cat Act 2011 requires owners desex, microchip and register their pets by the time they're six months old.

Cats should also wear an identification in public places.

But only 14 of the 139 LGAs﻿ reported high registration and microchipping compliance.

Just 17 reported high desexing compliance, and only five reported high levels of responsible pet cat ownership awareness.

﻿As well as putting cats at risk of illness and injury, low rates of responsible cat ownership in WA threatens the welfare and conservation of native wildlife.

But is permanent cat containment legislation (banning cats from roaming outdoors) the right solution?

An increasing body of research has shown that keeping cats indoors full-time and limiting outdoor access to enclosed areas or while on a leash is better for the cat's welfare.

It's also better for the ﻿welfare of other animals domestic cats often prey upon.

But many owners who allow their cats to roam are staunchly against such measures.

Low rates of responsible cat ownership in WA threatens the welfare and conservation of native wildlife. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

﻿According to the research, only three LGAs in WA have been successful in introducing permanent cat containment laws to keep cats indoors.

Others have tried but failed.

Despite this, 80 of the 103 LGAs surveyed said they would introduce permanent cat containment laws if there was a clear pathway to implementation.

"Many LGAs in WA want to (and many have tried to) implement restrictions to prevent pet cats from roaming, with limited success and considerable frustration," the report read.

title: Frantic dual citizens scramble to order new passports amid major change
text:
A﻿ustralian-British dual citizens now have less than one month to prepare for the United Kingdom's new Electronic Travel Authorisation (ETA) scheme.

The UK will soon strictly enforce its ETA scheme from February 25; a big change which means dual Australian-British or Australian-Irish nationals – who are exempt from needing an ETA – must have a valid UK or Irish passport to travel in and out of Britain or Ireland.

After Nine.com.au first reported on the upcoming changes﻿, countless dual citizens living in Australia with expired passports have been left wondering how it will impact their travel plans or if their forthcoming trips have been ruined.

READ MORE: ﻿ Thousands join Invasion Day rallies around the country

Dual British-Australian citizens need a valid UK passport to travel back to Britain from February 25. (Getty)

Do you have a story? Contact reporter April Glover at april.glover@nine.com.au

It triggered such a huge response from concerned travellers that the Briti﻿sh High Commission in Canberra has stepped in to clear up any confusion.

Here are some of the biggest questions surrounding the ETA scheme, answered.﻿

Who needs to pay for an ETA and who doesn't?﻿

Travellers from 85 countries, including Australia, will need to apply for an ETA to enter England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland as a visitor.

The ETA costs ﻿£16 (approximately $32) and it lasts for two years, allowing multiple visits for up to six months at a time.

British and Irish citizens, however, won't need to apply for an ETA to visit.

They will instead be required to travel on a valid British or Irish passport.﻿

"You must use your UK passport or a certificate of entitlement to travel to the UK", Deputy High Commissioner Dr Brian Jones said in a video shared online.

"From the 25th of February this year, you may be denied boarding on departure if you don't have this when you travel to the UK."

READ MORE: Hundreds flee homes as Victoria bushfire breaks containment

Dr Brian Jones was appointed Deputy British High Commissioner to Australia in July 2025. (Facebook)

What is a certificate of entitlement?﻿

A ﻿certificate of entitlement can be used instead of a British passport and is proof of your right to abode in the UK.

Importantly, you cannot get a certificate if you already have a British passport or a valid certificate of entitlement in another foreign passport.

It will cost £589 (approx. $1163) for anyone applying outside the UK and it can take around three weeks for your application to be approved.﻿

An HM Passport Office in the Victoria area of central London. (Getty)

I am British and my children were born in Australia. Do they need a British passport too?

British citizenship is normally passed down to children who are born outside of the UK to a British parent.﻿

Jones said impacted citizens will need to check their child's specific circumstances before travelling after February 25.

"If they are British, you will need a British passport for them or a certificate of entitlement," Jones said.

"If you believe you could be British, especially if you've got British parents, head to gov.uk to review your eligibility.

"It is complex, but you may be eligible depending on when you were born, where you were born, and your parents' citizenship at the time of your birth."

My ETA doesn't expire until after February 25. Can I still use it even if I am a British citizen?

Jones said British citizens should not travel on an ETA after February 25, even if it was granted before the new rules kick in.

﻿If you need to travel urgently to the UK, however, he said you may be eligible for an emergency travel document.

You can apply for an ETA on the UK ETA app. (Supplied)

I am arriving in the UK before Feb 25, am I affected?

﻿The short answer is: no.

﻿The UK will not enforce the new ETA scheme until after February 25.

If you are travelling to the UK before this date, Australian travellers won't need to pay for an ETA﻿ and dual citizens won't need their valid UK passport just yet.

How long will it take to renew ﻿my passport?

It depends on whether you have had a Bri﻿tish or Irish passport before.

It can take between six to 13 weeks receive a passport from Australia.

This process time can vary and may be longer if you've never had a passport before.﻿

The HM Passport Office recommends ﻿that people do not book travel or apply for visas until after you have your passport.

title: 'A gift from the Australian people'
text:
Sporting legend Cathy Freeman has been awarded Australia's highest honour, a little more than 25 years after she sent the nation into a frenzy with her Olympic gold medal at Sydney 2000.

Other notable names to be appointed as a companion of the Order of Australia (AC) tonight include former premiers Kristina Keneally, Annastacia Palaszcuk and Steven Marshall, and former federal finance minister Mathias Cormann.

In all, nearly 1000 Australians were recognised in the﻿ Australia Day 2026 Honours List, including awards in the Order of Australia (General and Military Divisions), meritorious awards, and recognition for distinguished and conspicuous service.

Cathy Freeman crossing the finish line and winning gold in the 400 metres at the Sydney 2000 Olympics. (Getty)

It's just the latest in a glittering list of achievements and awards for Freeman, undoubtedly one of Australia's greatest athletes, responsible for the country's most iconic sporting moment.

She already counted Australian of the Year, Young Australian of the Year, Sport Australia Hall of Fame Legend status and the Order of Australia Medal alongside her Olympic gold and silver medals and three Commonwealth Games golds in her trophy cabinet.

The Kuku Yalanji and Birra Gubba woman was recognised for "eminent service to athletics as an international competitor and ambassador, to positive social impact across the community, to the reconciliation movement in the spirit of unity and inclusion, and as a role model to youth."

Freeman told The Sydney Morning Herald she intended to use the honour as a platform to unite Australia.

"Mum said this is a gift from the Australian people and I wouldn't have looked at it that way, but my mum has incredible wisdom. So I sort of just stopped overthinking it and took it in the spirit it's supposed to be received in," she said, adding her mum was "all about unity".

"I just want to be who I am, be authentic. My achievement and my story is always going to touch on things like Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander perspectives, Olympism, track and field, elite sport, women in sport, the themes are diverse and varied."

Cathy Freeman celebrates with her gold medal after winning the Women's 400m final at the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games. (Getty)

Freeman described the award as "quite mind-bending".

"I set out to be the best athlete that I could be for myself and then all of a sudden this whole world unfolded right before my very eyes, and it just continues to expand, and it continues to be a wild ride, let me tell ya," she said.

Palaszczuk, who won widespread support among Queenslanders but angered many in the rest of the country by limiting the local impact of the COVID-19 pandemic through harsh border restrictions, was praised for her recognition to public health.

She was also recognised more generally for her time as premier and service to educational equity and multiculturalism.

Then Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk during a press conference following a national cabinet meeting at Parliament House in Canberra on Wednesday 6 December 2023. (The Sydney Morning Herald)

Rob Hirst, the Midnight Oil drummer who died just days ago follow an almost three-year battle with pancreatic cancer , was appointed a member of the order for his service to music.﻿

The Council of the Order of Australia highlighted former federal finance minister Cormann for his contributions to government reform, multilateral affairs and international economic development.

The Belgian-born Australian politician became secretary-general of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) shortly after leaving the Senate.

Former NSW leader Kristina Keneally was recognised for her services as premier, as well as her later years as a federal senator.

Former South Australian premier Steven Marshall was recognised for his service to business, people with disability, governance and board positions.﻿

In addition to the 680 recipients of awards in the General Division of the Order of Australia (10 AC, 38 AO, 160 AM and 472 OAM), today's Honours list includes:

22 recipients of awards in the Military Division of the Order of Australia.

187 Meritorious awards

60 Distinguished and Conspicuous awards

You can search the table below for the full list of honourees.﻿

READ MORE: Police respond to potential sighting of accused triple murderer

Governor-General Sam Mostyn said the honourees reflected Australia's values for service, community, kindness, curiosity, tenacity, and care.

"Congratulations to everyone recognised in the Australia Day 2026 Honours List," she said.

"As the list so vividly showcases, so many Australians continue to give the best of themselves across many endeavours, in the interest of others. It is rewarding to see an increase in the number of awards, which reflects more nominations and recognition of the many Australians who inspire the best in all of us."

title: Has your bedtime routine gone out the window over the school holidays?
text:
Before her twins started their first year of school, Brisbane mother Rose Stenhouse implemented what she called a screen time "detox".

"We have found screen time has definitely crept up over the holidays and behaviour has suffered," she said.

Rose Stenhouse said her children's screen time had crept up over the holidays. (ABC News: Charlie McLean)

Like so many others, Ms Stenhouse has been navigating how best to help her kids transition from holiday mode to healthy screen habits, with a regular sleep routine.

Experts in psychology and sleep say a "gentle reset" is key to helping kids adjust to a new routine.

Screen time not 'inherently harmful'

University of Queensland associate professor Asaduzzaman Khan said focusing on what kids are doing on their screens might be more useful than agonising over exact time limits.

"Passive screen use like mindless scrolling or watching YouTube videos without any mental engagement is more detrimental than active screen use," he said.

Screen time isn't inherently harmful, experts say. (ABC News: Luke Stephenson)

But Mr Khan said screen time isn't "inherently harmful".

"Educational games, creating apps, making videos; these are certainly good active screen uses," he said.

Less than an hour of sedentary screen time per day is recommended for children, aged between three and five, under the national guidelines.

It is recommended children aged between five and 17 have no more than two hours of sedentary screen time per day, although that does not include screen time needed for schoolwork.

Mr Khan said one of the best things parents could do was to model the behaviour themselves.

"You cannot set one rule for parents and one rule for kids. During dinner time if I check my email, it isn't giving a good message to the kids," he said.

" Making a family plan is critical because each family is different and each kid is different. "

Like with sleep routines, Mr Khan said it's about a "gentle reset" rather than a sudden ban on screen use.

"Some families might need a couple of weeks, but I think without a family plan, then it is difficult to attain any positive outcome on this journey."

How to help kids get into sleeping mode'

Dr Chris Watling from the University of Southern Queensland, who focuses on sleep, said introducing changes to routines gradually was a helpful approach.

"You might want to try and bring their bedtime back between 15 and 30 minutes every day," he said.

Dr Chris Watling says optimising a child's sleep environment can help them settle back into the school routine. (Supplied)

Creating a calming pre-bedtime routine is essential, Dr Watling said.

"Avoid phones, tablets and TVs one hour before bed and try to engage in relaxing activities," he said.

"Try to spend a little bit of extra time reading so they can slowly start to calm down and get into that sleeping mode."

Avoiding screen time in the hour before bedtime can help the routine, Dr Watling says. (ABC News: Glyn Jones)

Dr Watling said keeping the bedroom dark, cool and quiet and dropping down the lights throughout the house about an hour before bed could send the right signal.

Parents can also make changes during the day, like making sure kids get outside in the morning.

"Morning sunlight helps to reset our body clock. It's a really fundamental part of sleep science."

Being a bit stricter and enforcing bedtime habits might be necessary, he said.

At Brisbane's Sherwood State School, parents of the incoming Prep cohort said they had tried to prepare their children for the next stage in their development.

Matt Kendall says it can be a bit hard to get his two boys to bed on time. (ABC News: Charlie McLean)

"[We've] been trying to get them to bed early," Brisbane father-of-two Matt Kendall said.

"It's a bit hard with the boys, they just want to keep playing but we're just trying to get to bed early and [establish] a bit of a routine."

Dr Watling said modelling good sleep habits could help.

"Let the kids know that when you went back to work you had to stop staying up late or whatever it is that you were doing on the holidays as an adult," he said.

For larger families, discussing bedtime at the dinner table could be a good way to go, he said.

The impact of poor sleep

Paying attention in school is the biggest issue in children who haven't had enough sleep, Dr Watling said.

"The research shows us that the ability to maintain attention will drift off. Naturally, that happens anyway, but when we're sleep restricted that drifting off starts to happen a lot earlier and frequently. We've already got an uphill battle against that."

Emotional regulation and communicating with fellow students can also be victims of poor sleep.

"We all know when we've had a bad night's sleep as adults, we might get a little narky with our friends the next day. You can imagine how that can be even more problematic with children."

title: Levi sisters turn down NRLW to re-sign with Rugby Australia
text:
Australian rugby sevens star Maddison Levi admits an NRLW cameo with sister Teagan would have been "selfish" after re-signing with Rugby Australia on a two-year deal.

Spurred by a heartbreaking Olympic campaign in Paris, the Levi sisters have given themselves another shot at gold medal glory and will remain with Australia's rugby sevens program until at least the end of 2028.

The pair were expected to announce a one-off NRLW cameo this year, with various media outlets reporting RA had ticked off negotiations with a rugby league club.

It is not the first time Maddison, 23, and Teagan, 22, have expressed interest in a cross-code move, with Rugby Australia knocking back a request at the end of 2024.

The older Levi sister has also played AFLW, featuring in eight games for the Gold Coast Suns in 2021.

Maddison Levi is one of the best rugby sevens players in the world. (Getty Images: Hannah Peters)

Maddison, recognised as perhaps the world's best women's sevens player, said the decision factored in a short turnaround from the international sevens season ending on June 7 to the NRLW opening round from July 2.

"We'd be coming straight off a season into an NRLW season," Maddison said on Tuesday.

"The toll our body takes under sevens, and to not have a pre-season underneath us and go out and play league, it's probably a bit selfish on our part, not having played before.

"Teags, being a half or a playmaker, she can't really play-make much if people don't know how she plays.

"Being well-known sevens athletes, going over there, we want to go over and make our mark.

"And if we go over under-prepared — not that we can't do that, I'm sure we could go out there and show how we play in sevens — but we wanted to fully be able to transition and show the NRLW how we play."

The Levi sisters are keen to make amends for a disappointing campaign at the Paris Olympics two years ago. (Getty Images: Cameron Spencer)

The pain of a disastrous Olympic campaign in 2024 still lingers for the sisters, with Australia forced to leave Paris without a medal after two mighty upsets relegated them to a fourth-place finish.

Left rattled, the lure of an Olympic gold medal and redemption was strong enough for the sisters to turn down a lucrative deal from an NRLW club.

"Money, it's nice, but it's not the be-all and end-all," Maddison said.

"We both play for the love of the game and ultimately, that's kind of why we turned it down.

"Paris left us all a bit rattled. We were in the best position to get that Olympic gold medal.

"You look back and the time in the village is good, and then you think of the games.

"It's such a conflicting memory, but it's something that's going to drive us to be hungrier come LA.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"They say you can't win one without losing one — we've lost enough now to have a gold medal in LA."

But the door to a cross-code move is not completely shut, with Australia set to host the 2029 Women's World Cup.

"A hundred per cent, to be a dual athlete would be such a surreal experience. It's definitely not off the cards," Teagan said.

"I went and played at the (Super Rugby team Queensland) Reds for a little bit, and that was a great experience in itself.

"Again, the timing didn't really work out with the seasons, but that door's definitely not shut either."

AAP

title: NT public schools mandated to sing national anthem at assemblies
text:
The Northern Territory government has mandated public school students to sing the Australian national anthem during assemblies and special events.

Under the policy introduced today, all 152 of the territory's public schools will be directed to play and sing both verses of the anthem in English during school assemblies and special events.

Students will also be expected to stand while the anthem is played.

In a statement, Education Minister Jo Hersey said Territory children had "been deprived of feeling proud to be Australian" and the new policy would restore national pride.

"We are Australian, and in the Northern Territory students will be taught what it means to be an Australian and to be proud of their country," she said.

Students at all 152 of the territory's public schools will be required to stand for and sing the Australian national anthem. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

The policy also includes an update to the school curriculum for students to learn about national symbols and what they mean to Australian identity through the civics and citizenship learning area.

Singing and performing the anthem can also be taught as part of arts lessons.

Ms Hersey says that while singing the anthem will become mandatory, performing a Welcome to Country will be at the discretion of each school.

According to the NT Council of Government School Organisations' (NTCOGSO) website, approximately 43 per cent of NT public school students are Indigenous.

The mandate will be in place for all government schools in the territory. (Facebook: NT Department of Education)

Federal minister backs policy

Federal Education Minister Jason Clare said the singing of the anthem "already happens a lot" in schools across Australia.

"I never knew the second verse until I became a pollie, but you go to schools across the country, and kids sing the first verse and the second verse," he told Channel 7's Sunrise program.

"There's a great line in the second verse which says 'with courage let us all combine to Advance Australia Fair' … if kids are singing that in the NT and in other parts of the country I reckon that's a good thing."

The policy comes in time for the beginning of the new school year, with public school students starting on Thursday.

title: Kanye West says he 'lost touch with reality' due to brain injury
text:
Ye, the rapper and entrepreneur formerly known as Kanye West, has again apologised for antisemitic remarks, this time taking out a full-page ad in the Wall Street Journal.

"I lost touch with reality," Ye wrote in the ad, attributing his behaviour to an undiagnosed brain injury and an untreated bipolar disorder.

"I regret and am deeply mortified by my actions in that state, and am committed to accountability, treatment and meaningful change."

Kanye West denied entry to Australia, minister reveals The musician had a valid visa cancelled by officials in Tony Burke's department after he released a song titled Heil Hitler.

Ye has made numerous antisemitic public statements over the past few years, including a social media post that appeared to accuse notorious musician Sean "Diddy" Combs of being controlled by "the Jewish people" and another that appeared to show a swastika symbol inside a Star of David.

In October 2022, Ye wore a White Lives Matter shirt — a phrase adopted by neo-Nazi and white supremacist groups in response to the Black Lives Matter movement — to a Paris Fashion Week event.

After a backlash, he posted to Twitter that he would go "death con 3 on Jewish people".

His tweet was taken down and his Twitter and Instagram accounts were restricted for violating community guidelines.

He was reinstated eight months later after Elon Musk took over the social media platform and rebranded it as X.

Regrets using swastika imagery

Ye wrote that his diagnosis does not excuse his behaviour.

"I am not a Nazi or an antisemite," he said. "I love Jewish people."

Ye also voiced regrets for past expressions of admiration for Adolf Hitler and the use of swastika imagery.

Last year, federal Immigration Minister Tony Burke revealed that Ye had been denied a visa to Australia after releasing an antisemitic song.

Ye's next album, Bully, is due out on Friday, according to the Spotify website.

A previous album, VULTURES 1, a collaboration with fellow American rapper Ty Dolla $ign, saw two major artists, Ozzy Osborne and Donna Summer, publicly accuse West of copyright infringement.

The American Anti-Defamation League, which tracks antisemitism, issued a statement describing his apology as overdue and noting his prior antisemitic remarks.

"Ye's apology to the Jewish people is long overdue and doesn't automatically undo his long history of antisemitism — the antisemitic 'Heil Hitler' song he created, the hundreds of tweets, the swastikas and myriad Holocaust references — and all of the feelings of hurt and betrayal it caused," an ADL spokesperson said.

"The truest apology would be for him to not engage in antisemitic behaviour in the future.

"We wish him well on the road to recovery."

When Adidas cut ties with Ye it was left with more than a billion dollars worth of high-end Yeezy sneakers. (AP: Seth Wenig)

'In reality you're losing your grip'

This is not the first time Ye has apologised for antisemitism, after he issued an apology in Hebrew in December 2023 for "any unplanned outburst" and that he regretted any pain he may have caused.

In October 2022, sportswear brand Adidas cut ties with Ye, who had launched a high-end sneaker brand with the company, called Yeezy.

Ye issues apology to Jewish community The rapper Ye, formerly known as Kanye West, has issued an apology in Hebrew to the Jewish community for his past antisemitic remarks, saying he sought forgiveness and regretted any pain that his words had caused.

Balenciaga and Gap also ended their fashion partnerships with Ye, while retailers Foot Locker and TJ Maxx stopped selling the Yeezy brand.

In the full-page ad, Ye referred to his struggles with his mood disorder over the years.

"Bipolar disorder comes with its own defence system. Denial," he wrote.

"When you're manic, you don't think you're sick.

"You think everyone else is overreacting.

"You feel like you're seeing the world more clearly than ever, when in reality you're losing your grip entirely."

Hitting rock bottom

Ye wrote that 25 years ago he was in a car accident that caused significant brain damage that wasn't properly diagnosed until 2023.

He added that the medical oversight caused mental health problems that led to his bipolar type-1 diagnosis.

The songwriter said that being in "a four-month-long manic episode of psychotic, paranoid and impulsive behaviour" in early 2025 destroyed his life.

Kanye West is being accused of copyright infringement. Here's what you need to know Kanye West's new collaborative album VULTURES 1 arrived on Saturday. And it's already stirring up drama.

Ye added that he "hit rock bottom a few months ago" and had thoughts of not wanting "to be here anymore".

The Gold Digger rapper also addressed the black community with both appreciation and more apologies, saying it was "unquestionably, the foundation of who I am".

"I am so sorry to have let you down. I love us."

Previously, Ye said he was on the autism spectrum rather than having a bipolar disorder.

However, looking through Reddit posts of other "manic" people helped him to feel he was "not alone" and understand that he had a chronic mood disorder, he said.

Reuters/ABC

title: How the Perth Scorchers have torched the competition
text:
Despite their titan status, the Perth Scorchers were not favourites to win heading into this season.

Finals forecasts were mostly split between reigning champions the Hobart Hurricanes, and Perth's rival hegemon the Sydney Sixers.

The Sixers boasted an experienced bowling attack and a star-studded batting line-up — featuring newly signed Babar Azam, the most prolific men's T20 International batter in the world.

Perth, on the other hand, had just lost AJ Tye and Jason Behrendorff to the Melbourne Renegades, and Lance Morris to injury, and was still processing a rare missed finals series.

The glory days were over for the Scorchers, some said. It was time for someone else to take the crown.

This weekend, formerly sceptical pundits swallowed their words as Perth added a sixth trophy to its cabinet, extending its record as the most decorated team in the BBL.

The Perth Scorchers have won six out of 15 completed Big Bash League seasons. (AAP Image: Richard Wainwright)

The Sixers were left to lick their wounds, board a flight home and, according to a statement released post-game, "shift focus to reflection".

The question undoubtedly up for discussion — for Sydney and other clubs in the league — is how to replicate Perth's success.

Succession planning tricky for clubs

Title-winning player groups are easy to mythologise and hard to replace.

Failing to relinquish aging stars at the right time is a common trap in all formats — particularly for clubs that have enjoyed prolonged golden eras.

The Scorchers claimed their fifth BBL title in 2023. (Getty Images: Cricket Australia/Matt King)

Over the past decade, Perth captain turned coach Adam Voges and high-performance general manager Kade Harvey have delivered a masterclass in succession planning.

The club has managed to hang onto a core group of players to serve as mentors and cultural torch bearers, like Ashton Turner — now the only skipper in the league to lead his team to three titles.

At the same time, they have been consistently scouting and folding in young homegrown talent — an investment which paid dividends this season with Cooper Connolly and Mahli Beardman deftly stepping up in an injury hit bowling side.

For the most part, imports have been treated as supplementary, with culture and team fit valued over records and star factor.

One win in three games left Scorchers on the brink. Enter Ashton Turner Ashton Turner narrowly misses out on a maiden BBL century as he helps launch Perth to a crucial 71-run win over the Sydney Thunder.

Sunday night's man of the match, David Payne, fellow English import Laurie Evans, and Kiwi opener Finn Allen — none of whom were major headline selections — are illustrative of this approach.

All have proven themselves this season to be team players — willing to fit in wherever, whenever — and come across in interviews as being genuinely bought into the Scorchers as a club.

It is a strategy the Sixers may look to model moving forward after the much-hyped addition of Azam proved a costly, ultimately unsuccessful experiment.

After failing with the bat — and butting heads with Steve Smith — he departed the Sixers the day before they were set to play the Hurricanes in a final on Friday, leaving Sydney to recall veteran opener Daniel Hughes at the last minute.

'The Furnace' bears fruit

Asked about the secret to their success this week, Jhye Richardson pointed to two key factors: their adaptability as a playing group, and the fear-inspiring "fortress" that is "the Furnace".

The Furnace, aka Perth Stadium, has been the Scorchers' home ground since 2018, when they relocated from the WACA — a move masterminded by then head of cricket WA, Christina Matthews.

The Perth Scorchers have captured the imagination of young cricket fans in the west. (ABC News: Lauren Smith)

Matthews, who received significant pushback at the time, said it was the best decision she ever made.

"There was a lot of angst around moving there, not being a traditional home of cricket," she said.

"People were nervous about what the appetite was to have bigger crowds than what we had at the WACA.

" I just sat there [Sunday night] so pleased I was able to be part of something that has changed the nature of cricket in WA. "

A crowd of 55,018 filed into Perth Stadium to watch the Scorchers thump the Sixers. (ABC News: Lauren Smith)

The final saw the Scorchers draw a record home crowd of more than 55,000 fans, who have earned themselves a reputation for being the most parochial and energetic 12th man in the BBL.

The move also compelled the club to adapt their playing style — developing a deep, aggressive batting line-up capable of navigating one of Australia's most challenging wickets.

Challenges ahead for teams

The worst thing about being top of the table is the title is yours to lose.

The task ahead of the Scorchers is maintaining their hegemony and, for WA Cricket, ensuring that success is shared.

Next year, continuity will be challenged as Voges steps down from managing the state team, though he will remain at the helm of the Scorchers.

Josh Inglis and Cooper Connolly (right) celebrate the winning runs. (AAP Image: Richard Wainwright)

It will mark the first time that coaching position has been split, meaning collaboration will be required to integrate younger players like Beardman and Connolly into first-class and one-day cricket while balancing their BBL commitments.

Harvey will undoubtedly be crucial in this transition as he remains the list manager for both teams.

Teams will be able to nominate a designated batter and fielder from next season under a new rule to be introduced for BBL|16.

The change — which will undoubtedly prolong the careers of aging stars — and the push to privatise will also rock the boat.

"The states will have a really strong role to play in deciding who their partners are," Matthews said on privatisation, which she sees as "inevitable".

Christina Matthews says the next task is to bring WA's women's league up to the same level. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

"The Scorchers and WA Cricket could make that a non-negotiable about how they want to see the team put together, how they manage things.

"They've won the most titles ... WA should really leverage that."

Matthews said another item on the to-do list — bringing WA's women's leagues up to the same level of consistency — would be a true marker of comprehensive success for the state.

Whatever happens, the Scorchers have etched their names deeper into the history books with this win, guaranteeing them titan status for years to come.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

title: Live: Sabalenka beats the heat to blast into AO semifinals
text:
Near record temperatures are forecast for day 10 of the Australian Open, featuring the start of the singles quarterfinals.

Top seed Aryna Sabalenka powered past American teenager Iva Jović 6-3, 6-0 in another ominious display to become the first woman into the semifinals.

Alex de Minaur faces world number one Carlos Alcaraz on Rod Laver Arena, but in the day session 2025 runner-up Alexander Zverev takes on another rising American in Learner Tien.

Follow all the latest from Melbourne Park in our live blog below.

Key Events Aryna Sabalenka cruises into semifinals in straight sets 14 minutes ago Near-record temperatures on Australian Open day 10 2 hours ago Melbourne Park to become a furnace 2 hours ago Who's playing in the Australian Open quarterfinals today? J By Jon Healy Here is the match schedule for the main draw singles quarterfinals on Rod Laver Arena on day 10 (all times AEDT): Aryna Sabalenka (1) vs Iva Jović (29) from 11:30am

Alexander Zverev (3) vs Learner Tien (25) not before 1:30pm

Coco Gauff (3) vs Elina Svitolina (12) from 7pm

Carlos Alcaraz (1) vs Alex de Minaur (6) Some Sabalenka stats D By Dean Bilton (Getty Images) Just a handful of numbers here from that match which tell the story of Sabalenka's dominance: Aces 7-1

First serve win % 83-55

Winners 31-12



Break points won 4/9 - 0/5

Total points won 67-45 Aryna Sabalenka cruises into semifinals in straight sets D By Dean Bilton (Getty Images) Utterly comprehensive. Sabalenka raced to a 3-0 lead in the first set, before Iva Jovic showed admirable fight to make the world number sweat her to a 6-3 win. But in the second set, as the temperature soared, Sabalenka put her foot down. 6-0 accurately reflects the dominance, the power and the confidence of a woman who looks well and truly on track for a third title here at the Australian Open. Jovic certainly caught the attention this fortnight and looks a star of the future. Unfortunately she just happened to run into the biggest star of the present, and found out what the top really looks like. Sabalenka breaks again. 5-0 D By Dean Bilton Iva Jovic's resistance has broken, as a double fault hands Sabalenka another break of serve and offers her the opportunity to serve for this match in quick time. Both women are dreaming of an ice bath and some air con by now, I reckon. Heat scale cracks four as Sabalenka breaks again D By Dean Bilton (Getty Images) She's a class above, the world number one. Jovic sends a stretched backhand long to hand Sabalenka the double break in this second set. In other news, the official Australian Open heat scale has just nudged its way up to level four, which means it is just one away from outside matches being halted and the roof being shut where possible. At this rate, that's not going to be a problem for these two. Sabalenka is closing in on her semifinal. Another breezy hold. 4-0. Sabalenka looking imperious D By Dean Bilton I've been impressed with Jovic's power in this match, and all tournament to be honest. She certainly packs a punch despite not being the physically biggest player on the circuit. But it still pales in comparison to what Sabalenka can produce. She is fighting fire with fire and coming out on top. Another hold sealed with an ace. Jovic fighting but Sabalenka presses on D By Dean Bilton Iva Jovic has certainly got a bit of heart about her. Plenty of others would have wilted under that sort of early Sabalenka pressure, but the teenager did not take a backward step in the first set. She's still a set down though and will need something special to knock off the world number one. I'll tell you what won't help Jovic's cause though. Getting broken in the first game of the second set. A few untimely errors in the face of Sabalenka's powerful groundstrokes coughs up the advantage immediately. 'No pain no gain' S By Simon Smale I, for one, hate it when you can't find a pad to write your motivational quotes on. I can't see any of my colleagues being too happy with me writing it on their face instead, though - which is why I have refrained from writing anything on Dean for ages. He's here to take you through the second set. I'm not sold, still S By Simon Smale Vermont is the U.S. state synonymous with serving apple pie with cheese, but it should specifically be a sharp cheddar. Not the only dessert with cheese, there's also cannoli, knafeh, crostata, vatrushka, topfenstrudel, etc. Must hit that salty/sweet combo, so maybe there is something to the apple pie and cheddar combo! - Kate Sabalenka finally holds to win the first set! S By Simon Smale Wowza, what a battle! The longest game of the match so far at over 10 minutes long but Sabalenka survives it to take a set to love lead. (Getty Images) Sabalenka was put under pressure in that service game - she lost a point on first serve for the first time in the match so far, for one. Jović even managed to force a break point to really put the cat amongst the pigeons. But then those pigeons unloaded the rocket propelled grenade and blasted a monstrous ace to stave off that break point - her second of the game and fourth of the set. Jović still didn't go away, hitting a delightful winner to force deuce and then saw Sabalenka find the net to set up a second break point. Sabalenka saved that too, but Jović still didn't let up, a net cord from Sabalenka allowing Jović to come in and pounce with a winner for a third break point. The teenager's returning has been excellent, really forcing Sabalenka to think twice despite the power of her serve. But that service power was the difference in the end as Sabalenka held on to claim the set after 59 minutes. Jović holds again S By Simon Smale Sabalenka showed her pace and skill and touch by racing to a drop shot and earning a winner that made this hold more nervous for Jović But that was a big hold for the American. Had Sabalenka broken then and had the serve to start the second set, psychologically Jović would have always been behind. Just staying in the fight and keeping on the board is crucial for her heading into the second - not that the first is done yet - Sabalenka to serve for it. I'd expect so S By Simon Smale Are the empty seats on Rod Laver due to the hot weather? Surprising for a quarter final match. - Sinead Because you're absolutely right. It's never a good look for there to be any empty seats on a show court at any stage of a grand slam - let alone a quarterfinal. But the heat has to be taken into account I guess. Sabalenka a game away from the first set S By Simon Smale (Getty Images) It's strong stuff from Sabalenka. She went out to a 40-0 lead there but then dropped a couple of points off the back of a second double fault of the match. But a Jović unforced error puts Sabalenka on the brink of a set to love lead at 5-2. (Getty Images) Jović holds after 9-minute epic S By Simon Smale Wow, well done Iva Jović! She had to stave off two break points from 15-40 down, then another one in among a four-deuce extension to the game. But hold she did - a brave battle over 9 minutes and 23 seconds that will do her the world of confidence. There were flashes in that game of the way she has been able to aggressively control points like she has against all her opponents so far this tournament. But it's just so much harder to sustain against a player like Sabalenka who is just so powerful and loves to dictate things herself. Sabalenka's serve is sensational S By Simon Smale (Getty Images) Sealing a service game with an ace is not a bad way to do it. Sabalenka still hasn't lost a point when she's got her first serve in in this match — she's nine for nine. It's relentless. It's frankly, awesome. A stat just popped up that Sabalenka appears to have taken some speed off her first serve from last year, it's at 165km/h compared to 176km/h last year. But her average is back up at 176km/h today with a fastest of 188km/h. She leads 4-1. Jović gets on the board S By Simon Smale (Getty Images) That was a better, albeit, battling service game from Iva Jović. But the fear is that Sabalenka can still just out-muscle the teenaged American. Jović is getting caught in trying to exchange with the two-time champion from the baseline and is being beaten up as a result. Jović did mix things up on game point, throwing a slice or two in and a drop shot. But Sabalenka is a different beast this year, racing around the court and forcing the missed winner. (Getty Images) From there, Sabalenka struck, her relentlessness such a key factor in her success, to race into a break point chance. Jović fought hard to stave that off, and then got a bit of luck when a would-be winner clipped the net from Sabalenka. A good hold. A deserved hold. Less apple with the cheddar S By Simon Smale Hello Simon, the apple pie and cheese sounds good although I would substitute bacon and tomato for the apple... - Mike I think this suggestion is a good one, Mike. The thing that makes the whole concept a culinary crime is the addition of cheddar cheese to a sweet pasty though. So if you switch out the pasty for, I dunno, a burger bun, I reckon we're laughing. Loading Sabalenka serve at 100 per cent S By Simon Smale (Getty Images) Iva Jović crushed a brilliant winner off Aryna Sabalenka's second serve, stepping a pace inside the baseline and blistering a forehand into the open court. But it's only on the second serve that she's having success at the moment. Sabalenka has got six first serves in play so far and has won every point when she has. Sabalenka gets the early break S By Simon Smale That's impressive stuff from Aryna Sabalenka. (Getty Images) Iva Jović will need to be hitting her first serves if she is to have a chance in this game, but even getting them in didn't help her much in that game as Sabalenka won two of the three points when the first serve was made. A few unforced errors already in Jović's game, including sending the ball long on break point to surrender her serve. Sabalenka on the board first S By Simon Smale Strap yourselves in folks - this one is setting itself up nicely if this first game is anything to go by. Sabalenka came out with the power we expect, an ace to set up game point, an unreturnable serve to win it. But I get the feeling that bludgeoning her way across the court is not going to work as well as she hopes it will against Jović. The 18-year-old Jović hit an absolutely unreal backhand winner to open things up on the Sabalenka serve, two-handed, getting low and punching the ball to the baseline. It was a lovely shot and yes, only one point, but showed that she will not be bowed by the power. Sabalenka has more to her game than just brute force though - Luke Pentony wrote about that at the start of this tournament and it was in evidence in Brisbane as well. It should be a good test though, this. Show more posts

title: Surfers relish rare swell off Broome brought by ex-Tropical Cyclone Luana
text:
Dozens of surfers have relished the opportunity of rare waves off Western Australia's far north, with ex-Tropical Cyclone Luana behind the swell.

Cars lined the sand on Gantheaume Beach in Broome, as spectators and photographers caught a glimpse of surfers battling stormy weather.

Cars lined the beach to get a glimpse of the rare swell. (ABC Kimberley: Ruby Littler)

Conditions at the beach are usually flat, calm and glassy, but wind and rain from Luana, which crossed over the weekend as a category two system, stirred up more swell than normal.

Luana is currently a tropical low tracking inland and is expected to bring heavy rain to WA's interior in coming days.

'Definitely a miracle'

Broome resident Jac Coltman said it was great to see everyone out in the water.

Jac Coltman says locals have been treated to "really good waves". (ABC Kimberley: Dunja Karagic)

"It seems like everyone gets out when there's been a big storm, since it's the only time it brings in some good swell," Mr Coltman said.

"There's a real big current at the moment … so people are catching a few good ones. There is a bunch of people getting some really good waves."

Conditions were rough and choppy at Broome's Gantheaume Beach on Monday. (ABC Kimberley: Ruby Littler)

The prospect of irukandji jellyfish, crocodiles and sharks, all potential hazards of Broome's waters during the wet season, did not deter those keen to catch a wave.

"I'm more scared of irukandji than crocodiles, but there's a lot of swell so it'll push all them out," Mr Coltman said.

Kalani Henwood said while conditions could be better, for Broome, it was pretty good.

Kalani Henwood was among dozens of surfers catching waves at Gantheaume Beach. (ABC Kimberley: Ruby Littler)

"Every morning we're waiting, waiting for high tide, checking to see if there's surf … so it's made us all happy and made the town pretty happy too," Ms Henwood said.

" It's definitely a miracle, thank God. Everyone's been waiting for it. "

She said this was the first time she was able to get a decent surf after a year living in town.

"Bit washy, bit windy, bit of a hard paddle out, but it's fun … it's good to see everyone get out and be there together," Ms Henwood said.

'Brave souls'

Photographer Michael Torres, who runs a local surf account on Instagram, said he believed the surfing community was growing in Broome.

Michael Torres runs a surf photography account. (ABC Kimberley: Ruby Littler)

"A couple of days ago, I counted about 60 out there on the water, so it's definitely grown over the last few years," Mr Torres said.

"Good to see a lot of young people getting out there and a lot of the girls getting out there as well."

When describing the conditions since the cyclone, Mr Torres said it was definitely rougher than usual.

Irukandji jellyfish are known to be present in the water during Broome's wet season. (ABC Kimberley: Dunja Karagic)

"Bit messy and windy, but a couple of brave souls out there … a lot of swell, big dumpers and wind," he said.

"There's only a few of us taking photos out here, and it is unique getting the cyclone swell, so just doing my part taking photos for everyone."

title: Bradman still setting records as baggy green fetches top price
text:
A baggy green cap worn by Sir Donald Bradman in a series against India in 1947-48 has been sold for $460,000 at a Gold Coast auction, fetching the highest price for a cap sported by the great Australian batsman.

Bradman had given it to Indian cricketer Sriranga Wasudev Sohoni, whose family preserved it for the past 75 years.

Lee Hames, chief operating officer of Lloyds Auctioneers and Valuers, said the family had looked after the cap carefully.

Bradman's baggy green to go under the hammer A baggy green worn by Sir Donald Bradman during the 1947-48 series against India has gone to auction.

"That's over three generations under lock and key," he said.

"If you were a family member you were only allowed to look at it when you were 16 years old for five minutes."

It was sold to an anonymous bidder and will be kept on display at an Australian museum.

The cap, which has the names "D.G. Bradman" and "S.W. Sohoni" inscribed on the inside, is in good condition.

Another cap worn by Bradman was sun-faded and insect-damaged when it fetched $311,000 at auction in 2024.

Greatest batsman in history

Widely regarded as the greatest batsman in history, Bradman played 52 tests with a batting average of 99.94, nearly 40 runs higher than any other player.

The price paid for the cap, once a 16.5 per cent buyer's premium of $75,900 is added, totals $535,900, beating the previous record holder, a baggy green from the same series — against India in 1947/48 — that was sold in 2024.

The day a Bodyline bowler found himself pipped by pomegranates Flying fruit pips are less menacing than the cork and leather cricket balls that Harold Larwood hurled at Australian batsmen during the infamous Bodyline series, but a showdown between the English fast bowler and a disgruntled crowd that was allegedly armed with pomegranate seeds is part of the rich story of Ashes acrimony.

That cap was bought for $479,700, including the buyer's premium, at auction.

Back in Bradman's day, a baggy green cap was awarded for each series they played — a contrast to the present day where only one cap is handed out on Test debut.

Sohoni died in 1993, aged 75.

The 1947/48 series was notable for being India's first as an independent country and Bradman's last on home soil.

Bradman made it a memorable one, scoring 715 runs — including his 100th first-class century — as the Australians romped to a 4-0 series win.

AFP/Reuters

title: Australia's final Winter Olympians named as first athletes touch down in Italy
text:
Three alpine skiers have been officially added to finalise Australia's Winter Olympics team for the Milan-Cortina Games.

Phoebe Heaydon, Madison Hoffman and Harry Laidlaw were added to the 53-strong Australian team, which began to arrive in Italy yesterday.

Sydneysiders Hoffman and Heaydon will make their Olympic debuts in the slalom and giant slalom events.

Hoffman was selected for the Beijing 2022 Winter Olympics team but was injured just days out from the Games and had to withdraw.

PyeongChang 2018 Olympian Laidlaw will make his return in the giant slalom.

Harry Laidlaw was disqualified after missing a gate in the giant slalom at the 2018 Winter Olympics. (Getty Images: Matthias Hangst)

"Harry, Phoebe and Madison have each carved their own path through one of the most competitive global winter sports," Australian Winter Olympics team chef de mission Alisa Camplin said.

"Their selection is a testament to years of discipline, resilience and gritty performances. To be amongst the world's best is an outstanding achievement. I can't wait to see them in action.

"Harry has waited eight long years to get another run at the Games, and Madi has come back from the heartbreak of injury at Beijing 2022 and a double knee reconstruction. These are truly inspiring stories of determination and belief.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"Watching Phoebe's progression this season, to make her World Cup debut has been fantastic. She's only 20 years old. How great is it to see Australia's next-generation athletes rising to the top?"

Members of the aerials, cross-country and bobsleigh teams were the first athletes to arrive at the Australian Institute of Sport's European training centre in Varese, with an Aussie lunch held to coincide with Australia Day.

They were welcomed by Julianne Cowley, Australia's ambassador to Italy, and local officials.

The Milan-Cortina Games get underway on February 6 (local time).

title: Truckies drive 1,700km to deliver hay amid WA's deepening drought
text:
Years of little rainfall across an enormous stretch of Western Australia have given way to what some pastoralists are calling their worst drought in decades.

Cattle stations across WA's remote Midwest, Murchison and Gascoyne, an area larger than the state of Victoria, have received barely half their average annual rainfall in recent years.

While some are drier than others, it has forced 34 properties to call for help.

That call was answered in force by WA's agricultural community over the weekend, with seven road trains stacked high with emergency feed arriving in Gascoyne Junction, 945 kilometres north of Perth.

Seven road trains have carried emergency feed to Gascoyne Junction. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

The delivery of hundreds of hay bales was a welcome sight for pastoralists like Hamish McTaggart from Bidgemia Station.

Mr McTaggart told the ABC his property was experiencing its driest spell in 15 years, and possibly one of the worst since records began in 1875.

"There is a point where it doesn't matter how good you are as a farmer, the system just breaks down," he said.

"We're at that point at the moment."

Hamish McTaggart says he is experiencing one of the worst dry periods ever recorded at Bidgemia Station. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

Mr McTaggart said the uncertainty was taking a toll.

"You don't know when the end will be, so you're always hopeful that rain is just around the corner," he said.

" Not knowing where the end of it is — that's what worries you. "

More feed is due to head to the Upper Gascoyne in the coming weeks. (ABC Pilbara: Georgia Hargreaves)

It is a similar story 150km to the east at Landor Station, where owner Ritchie Brennan told the WA Country Hour he had gone three years without decent rainfall.

"It's the driest it's ever been since we've owned it," he said.

Mr Brennan purchased Landor Station 28 years ago.

Some stations in the Upper Gascoyne have not recorded a drop of rain in three years. (ABC Pilbara: Alistair Bates)

Aid almost derailed by bushfires

Farmers Across Borders vice president Roley Pearce said the land's poor condition was clear as he made the 1,700km journey north.

"It's just devastating," he said.

Roley Pearce led the Farmers Across Borders convoy. (ABC Pilbara: Alistair Bates)

More road trains are expected to arrive in the coming weeks.

Bushfires raging in WA's South West and Great Southern caused route and personnel changes up until the moment of departure.

"We've lost a few of the trucks that were coming on the run because the drivers are off fighting fires," he said.

"Otherwise, we would have had another four trucks here today."

Truckies and pastoralists swapped stories at the local watering hole. (ABC Pilbara: Alistair Bates)

Despite the challenges, he said the act of compassion was as important as the hay itself.

"At the end of it, a lot of the station owners have got that thought that somebody else does care about them, that they're not on their own," Mr Pearce said.

" That's what we're up against. "

Calls for state government support

This was the latest convoy launched by Farmers Across Borders, with the group establishing a reputation for the long-distance delivery of emergency feed.

Last year, the group rallied 85 trucks to deliver 6,000 bales of hay and straw to drought-stricken pastoralists in South Australia.

The run was subsidised by the South Australian government, which covered freight costs.

Jim Caunt is calling for the state government to pitch in. (ABC Pilbara: Alistair Bates)

Upper Gascoyne Shire President Jim Caunt said he wrote to WA Agriculture Minister Jackie Jarvis to ask if she would consider a similar scheme.

He is yet to receive a response.

"You've only got to look around here at just how spirits are lifted … from a half dozen trailers of hay that have arrived," he said.

" We need the support of the state government so that this can continue. "

Fuel for just one road train to and from Gascoyne Junction costs the charity group about $5,000, according to Mr Pearce.

Several pastoralists have destocked, with not enough feed to go around. (ABC Pilbara: Georgia Hargreaves)

Ms Jarvis declined to be interviewed.

But in a statement, she commended the organisation for its efforts and recognised some parts of the state had been more impacted due to "increased climate variability".

"I am currently seeking advice from the Department of Primary Industries and Regional Development on this evolving situation," she said.

"There is also a range of supports available through the Australian Government at Drought, disaster and rural support — DAFF."

title: Houseboat owners say they are forced out to protect million-dollar views
text:
A David and Goliath battle is playing out on the multi-million-dollar shores of the Noosa River, where dozens of houseboat residents say they are being forced out and potentially into financial ruin.

Since New Year's Day, Maritime Safety Queensland (MSQ) has been rolling out the final stage of its Noosa River Management Plan, which restricts boats larger than 5 metres from anchoring in the river for longer than 28 days.

Houseboats on the Noosa River. (ABC News: Tara Cassidy)

For dozens of people living on the river, it may mean they have until tomorrow to remove their boats or face hefty fines.

They also risk the potential removal and disposal of their homes and property by authorities.

More than 20 boats have already been towed, including several that were taken straight to the tip.

Sally Hayes says people will be left without somewhere to live. (ABC News: Tara Cassidy)

Sally Hayes lives in a houseboat on the river.

She said many of those affected had nowhere else to go and no way of paying to crane, relocate or store the boats elsewhere.

"There are people who've lived on this river for 35 years," she said.

"But more recently, with the homelessness crisis really exploding, there's been a lot of people who've moved onto boats simply because they can't afford to live anywhere else.

"And now what we've got is MSQ, backed by council, forcing these people off."

'A lot of homeless in rich little town'

Noosa River resident Bradley McMahon has lived in the area on and off for more than 30 years.

He said the changes also failed to consider that many of the boats were not equipped to move to other waters.

Bradley McMahon and his dog head back to their houseboat home on the Noosa River. (ABC News: Tara Cassidy)

"They're only built for rivers, lakes and estuaries," he said.

"They seem to forget that we have at the entrance to the river one of the most dangerous bar crossings in the country.

"So, if they force people to then crane their vessels [out], that's going to force them into financial hardship.

"This is affecting people's lives. There's already a lot of homeless people in this rich little town."

Bradley McMahon, Tya Gilleard, Sally Hayes and Rachel Hill are unhappy about the rule change. (ABC News: Tara Cassidy)

Ms Hayes said being forced off the river would also cost some residents their jobs.

Safer, more accessible river

The MSQ said the goal of the changes was "to make the river safer and more accessible for all waterway users".

The changes apply to the river and connecting waterways, creeks, surrounding lakes and the Noosa Everglades.

"Anyone experiencing genuine hardship should contact Maritime Safety Queensland," a spokesperson said.

" These changes are the result of extensive community consultation taking place since 2021. "

Maritime Safety Queensland patrols the Noosa River ahead of the new houseboat rules coming into force. (Supplied: Rachel Hills)

Derelict boats an 'eyesore'

The changes follow complaints from a number of Noosa riverfront property owners who have long argued the boats are an eyesore, and at times left abandoned and derelict.

Rachel Hill said she took out a loan to purchase her houseboat and planned to live in it from this year.

Rachel Hill says the rule change has upended her housing plans. (ABC News: Tara Cassidy)

But before ever getting to enjoy her live-aboard life, she was labelled a "freeloading scumbag" by a man who told her residents had "paid millions for our view".

"I just replied and kindly said, 'I'm not a freeloading scumbag, I have a loan to pay off, I work full-time, I pay rent, I work in aged care,'" she said.

" I'm sure the bloody houseboats were on the river when you bought your million-dollar views. "

Ms Hayes said the anchoring changes still would not solve the "eyesore" problem, with many of the worst boats able to remain because they were moored.

Many of the residents being forced out have been on mooring waitlists for years.

This houseboat is allowed to remain on the Noosa River because it is moored. (ABC News: Tara Cassidy)

"The boats that are being used, and actually housing people and being looked after, are being pushed off the river," she said.

"A lot of the colour, the fabric of Noosa is going to be gone, the people who make up this beautiful, vibrant community."

title: Gateway drills into WA Yandal gold discovery momentum
text:
Advertisement

Sponsored BusinessCompaniesBulls N' Bears Gateway drills into WA Yandal gold discovery momentum Brought to you by BULLS N’ BEARS Rowena Duckworth January 27, 2026 — 1:24pm Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share A A A

Gateway Mining has fired up the drill bit at its flagship Yandal gold project in Western Australia, bringing forward exploration plans to accelerate definition of the emerging Haflinger discovery and line up follow-up reverse circulation (RC) drilling in the coming weeks. The rods off two aircore rigs are now turning, with the first rig focused on infill and step-out drilling around Haflinger, where mineralisation has already been intersected over a strike length of approximately 500 metres. Initial drilling results have highlighted the system’s strength, despite several holes only clipping the targeted structure during first-pass programs. Drilling at Gateway Mining’s Yandal gold project in Western Australia. Standout intercepts from earlier drilling at Haflinger included a hefty 52 metres running at 1.4 grams per tonne (g/t) gold from 64 metres, including a higher-grade interval of 12m at a cool 3.1g/t gold. That campaign also returned 2m at 3.4g/t gold from 148m to bottom of hole, within a broader 6m grading 1.4g/t gold from 144m, and 4m going 2.9g/t gold from 148m within a broader 16m at 1.0g/t gold from 136m.

Advertisement

Gateway says the mineralisation tends to occur within a highly favourable structural setting, where the mafic–intermediate rock contact flexes to the south-east. Notably, drilling remains open to the south, where geological conditions appear to be improving, adding further upside to the discovery. ‘... Drilling remains open to the south, where the geology appears to become more favourable.’ Gateway Mining executive chairman Andrew Bray The first aircore rig is set to complete closer-spaced drilling to the north and south of existing intercepts to delineate the structure ahead of RC drilling. Management believes this next phase of drilling will be key to understanding the true scale of the Haflinger system. Meanwhile, the second aircore rig will systematically test the Mustang shear structure to the south, where Gateway is confident of making discoveries similar to Haflinger. Mustang offers a comparable geological setting, with significant deformation and complexity, supported by historic rotary air blast (RAB) drilling that returned anomalous gold results; however, it failed to penetrate the weathered profile adequately.

Advertisement

The company is keen to complete first pass drilling at Mustang as quickly as possible, allowing any discoveries to be rapidly followed up with RC drilling alongside Haflinger. Drilling plans have been ramped up to define the extent of the Haflinger discovery in preparation for follow-up RC drilling. Gateway Mining executive chairman Andrew Bray said: “Mineralisation at Haflinger has been intersected over approximately a 500m strike length to date, with the first two aircore holes clipping the targeted structure prior to blade refusal, and a third hole returning a spectacular result of 52m at 1.4g/t gold, including 12m at 3.1g/t gold. Drilling remains open to the south, where the geology appears to become more favourable.” The Haflinger find emerged from wide-spaced, shallow aircore along the company’s regional-scale Celia Shear structure, tapping into the same fertile structure that hosts the company’s existing 400,400-ounce, high-grade gold resource. RC drilling is scheduled to kick off in a little over six weeks. It will initially focus on the Great Western area, where widespread surface gold anomalism and abundant gold nuggets have been identified over a broad area within a highly favourable geological setting. As soon as the all-important assay results from the broader Mustang–Celia shear corridor aircore program hit the company inbox, drilling will pivot to initial RC programs at Haflinger and to any additional discoveries warranting follow-up.

Advertisement

The Yandal project sits strategically just 85 kilometres northeast of Wiluna, spanning a vast 1,780 square kilometres on the eastern flank of the world-class Yandal Greenstone Belt. The belt is one of Australia’s most prolific gold-producing regions and is home to Northern Star Resources’ Jundee mine, which lies within close proximity to Gateway’s tenure. Gateway’s broader Yandal project already hosts a resource of 8.17 million tonnes grading 1.52g/t gold for 400,400 ounces. The resource is centred on the Horse Well Gold Camp and the Dusk ’til Dawn deposit, providing a solid foundation for ongoing exploration success. With gold prices soaring, Gateway is wasting little time in pushing its Yandal gold strategy forward as it hunts for the next significant discovery in one of Western Australia’s most prolific gold belts. Two years ago, our reporter Angus Dalton experienced just what extreme heat can do to your body in a climate chamber on a 38-degree January day at about 20 per cent relative humidity.

As you read the lines below, spare a thought for the tennis players battling it out in today’s scorcher.

Reporter Angus Dalton spent time in a climate chamber. Credit: Photo: Brook Mitchel; Artwork: Marija Ercegovac

“Back in the chamber, after about 20 minutes, even sitting down doesn’t feel like a break,” Dalton wrote.

“It’s as if my body is working so hard to keep cool that my energy levels aren’t being replenished. The researchers can track the effects on core body temperature (measured by a digestible pill monitor), skin warmth and metabolic rate, as well as how much sweat a subject is losing and where it gathers on their bodies. In my case, we’ve tracked the effort my body has to make to keep cool by one simple measure: my heart rate.
